paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses variants in the TTR gene associated with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis, focusing on penetrance data and clinical significance.

patients.demographics: 21 pre-symptomatic carriers, 13 symptomatic patients; ages range from 45 to 73.5 years

individual_records.phenotype_details: No sensory or vegetative symptoms, normal neurological examination.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: We considered as carriers those subjects with no sensory or vegetative symptoms, normal neurological examination with a Neuropathy Impairment Scale (NIS) of 0–1.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Symptomatic patient with increased interventricular septum thickness and heart amyloid deposit.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: All symptomatic patients had both increased interventricular septum thickness and heart amyloid deposit at the bone scintigraphy.

functional_data.summary: The TTR variant leads to misfolded amyloidogenic protein causing multi-organ damage.

variants.segregation_data: The p.Val50Met mutation was more represented in pre-symptomatic subjects, suggesting familial segregation.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the importance of early detection in carriers.
key_quotes: Our study showed that sNfL reliably discriminates symptomatic ATTRv-PN patients from pre-symptomatic carriers.
sNfL levels were normal in all carriers, altered in 85% of patients.

tables_processed.table_caption: Demographic and diagnostic test variables in pre-symptomatic carriers and ATTRv patients with PN.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the TTR gene variants were extracted successfully.
